intro.description: This cheat sheet helps you to open an ascii file, and shows you how to use the measurement tool with the file. If you have just completed the previous cheat sheet, please close all your data file parts.

item.title: Data Browsing Perspective
item.description: Please choose the data browsing perspective if you do not already have it selected (nothing will happen if you do not).

item.title: Open File
item.description: Click to open an example file from the 'data' project containing multi-channel analyser data.

item.title: Plot One Data Set
item.description: In the 'Data' column of the part, select the item labelled 'Column 1'. This will plot the values of 'Column 1' vs. indices.

item.title: Select 'Measurement' tool
item.description: Select the measurement tool from the toolbar above the plot, tools labelled 'Plotting tools'. These tools may be obscured on Linux if the window containing the plot is too small.

item.title: Measure something
item.description: To measure between the peaks click and drag from one peak, letting go when you get to the next one. Repeat this between all the peaks in the file (to add each measurement, add a line region or simply press the button for the measurement tool again).

item.title: View measurements
item.description: Now look at the table in the 'Measurement' view below the plot. Each measurement is here with quantities shown.
item.onCompletion: Congratulations, you can now measure distances in X/Y plots. Try with your own ascii files or try some plotting using a hdf5 or nexus file with one or two dimensional data.
